rev.comment: /* Necrophilia as represented in the arts */
rev.diff:
Line 145: Line 145:
The [[My Chemical Romance]] song [[To The End]] is based on this story.
The [[My Chemical Romance]] song [[To The End]] is based on this story.
â
The 1987 german movie [[Nekromantik]] by director [[JÃ¶rg Buttgereit]] primarily deals with the theme of necrophilia, as does the sequel [[Nekromantik 2]].
+
The 1987 German movie [[Nekromantik]] by director [[JÃ¶rg Buttgereit]] primarily deals with the theme of necrophilia, as does the sequel [[Nekromantik 2]].
The 1994 [[Cormac McCarthy]] novel ''[[Child of God]]'' is a dark tale of a man who takes up life in a cave where he stores the corpses of his victims, and is one of the most remarkably sympathetic depictions of necrophilia in literature. The story is, however, more focused on extreme social alienation and the relationship we have with the outcast.
The 1994 [[Cormac McCarthy]] novel ''[[Child of God]]'' is a dark tale of a man who takes up life in a cave where he stores the corpses of his victims, and is one of the most remarkably sympathetic depictions of necrophilia in literature. The story is, however, more focused on extreme social alienation and the relationship we have with the outcast.
Line 163: Line 163:
The opening line of the [[Cradle of Filth]] song "Lord Abortion" from their album [[Midian (album)|Midian]], ("care for a little necrophilia, hm?") is a quote from Terry Gilliam's Brazil (voiced by Kim Greist in the film but delivered on the song by Toni King, the wife of the band's vocalist/co-creator Dani Filth).
The opening line of the [[Cradle of Filth]] song "Lord Abortion" from their album [[Midian (album)|Midian]], ("care for a little necrophilia, hm?") is a quote from Terry Gilliam's Brazil (voiced by Kim Greist in the film but delivered on the song by Toni King, the wife of the band's vocalist/co-creator Dani Filth).
â
The viedo for [[Tom Petty]]'s song [[Mary Jane's Last Dance]] depicts him stealing a corpse of a woman (played by [[Kim Basinger]]) from a morgue for a dinner date and clothing her in a wedding dress; at the end he throws her off a cliff into the sea.
+
The video for [[Tom Petty]]'s song [[Mary Jane's Last Dance]] depicts him stealing a corpse of a woman (played by [[Kim Basinger]]) from a morgue for a dinner date, clothing her in a wedding dress; at the end he throws her off a cliff into the sea.
